text:
The popular narrative right now is that AI is ‚Äúcoming for security‚Äù after the Claude Code Security announcement.

Claude Code Security is just static application security testing (SAST) where it reviews source code pre-deployment & flags issues like SQL injection. 

The market just repriced $50B+ of cybersecurity market cap off a headline that doesn‚Äôt actually threaten the core security stack: 

‚Ä¢ $CRWD secures live endpoints & cloud workloads after code is deployed while code scanning never sees what‚Äôs happening on the machine.
‚Ä¢ $ZS controls access & traffic between users, agents & applications while code scanning can‚Äôt see or block real-time network activity.
‚Ä¢ $NET runs a global network handling millions of requests per second while code scanning doesn‚Äôt see web traffic in flight.
‚Ä¢ $RBRK backs up & recovers data after ransomware and breaches while code scanning doesn‚Äôt restore anything once systems are hit.
‚Ä¢ $PANW inspects traffic across network, cloud & SecOps in production while code scanning doesn‚Äôt touch runtime environments.
‚Ä¢ $OKTA manages identity for humans & machine agents in production while code scanning doesn‚Äôt control logins or access.
‚Ä¢ $FTNT secures physical & virtual networks moving real packets while code scanning looks at source code rather than live traffic.
‚Ä¢ $S protects endpoints & workloads at runtime while code scanning only happens before deployment.

Claude Code Security looks at code before it ships but these platforms protect what happens after so this selloff is fear-driven and an opportunity.

$MSFT is near decade-low multiples with Azure sold out and Copilot embedding AI into 450M+ enterprise users.

They don‚Äôt need to ‚Äúwin AI‚Äù but just need to monetize the distribution they already own. No other company has this level of distribution for enterprise AI.

THE AGENTIC AI SECURITY CHEAT SHEET

The selloff in cybersecurity after Anthropic announced Claude Code Security is a perfect example of the market reacting to a headline instead of the actual product. 

This is what the real security stack looks like:

Identity & Access (who/what is allowed to act in production)
‚Ä¢ $ZS controls agent access & traffic across apps + networks
‚Ä¢ $OKTA manages identity & access for humans + machine agents

Endpoint & Workload Security (what runs on machines)
‚Ä¢ $S protects the machines & workloads agents run on
‚Ä¢ $CRWD is the interactive response layer for agents across endpoints & cloud workloads

Data Protection & Recovery (what must be protected after compromise)
‚Ä¢ $RBRK is the ‚Äúundo button‚Äù for AI agents when things go wrong

Network & Edge Security (how attacks move through systems)
‚Ä¢ $NET gatekeeper of agentic AI traffic on the modern internet
‚Ä¢ $FTNT secures AI traffic moving inside enterprise networks
‚Ä¢ $PANW coordinates security across network, cloud & SecOps
‚Ä¢ $AKAM protects applications & APIs at the edge where traffic hits first

Cloud Runtime & Vulnerability Exposure  (what is exploitable in production)
‚Ä¢ $RPD protects cloud workloads at runtime as deployments scale
‚Ä¢ $TENB maps & prioritizes exploitable vulnerabilities across live assets & cloud

Security Operations & Observability (how incidents are detected & acted on)
‚Ä¢ $DDOG provides real-time visibility into the infrastructure agents run on
‚Ä¢ $DT provides deep runtime visibility into applications  & APIs agents interact with

Claude Code Security sits at the application security layer scanning code for vulnerabilities and suggesting patches for human review. It's a useful feature but represents a VERY small slice of one layer of the broader security stack. 

AI doesn‚Äôt replace cybersecurity but will actually expand the attack surface.

Former $GOOGL CEO Eric Schmidt frames AI as an infrastructure + national security race with the U.S. structurally ahead of China on chips, capital and hyperscalers.

Every dollar of AI infrastructure spend is really a moat being built.

Sam Altman calls space-based data centers ‚Äúridiculous‚Äù given launch costs and power economics today.

This also reads like a direct rebuttal to the SpaceX + xAI orbital compute narrative Elon Musk has been pushing.

This constant ‚Äúdoomsday‚Äù narrative that we get every week about AI coming for software is getting nuts. 

A perfect example is Anthropic rolling out Claude Code Security today where this ‚Äúfeature‚Äù isn‚Äôt going to replace full cybersecurity ecosystems.

It‚Äôs like saying your apartment has a smoke detector so cities don‚Äôt need fire departments.. the smoke detector beeps but you still need the fire department to put out the fire and save the building. 

Claude Code can flag an issue but $CRWD responds to it, contains it and remediates across thousands of endpoints.

What are we even saying here  üòÖ

People think Claude Code security is coming for $CRWD, $ZS, $PANW, $NET or $RBRK.

This is what ‚ÄúAI-native security‚Äù looks like in practice.

Anthropic launched Claude Code Security in limited research preview, scanning codebases for vulnerabilities and suggesting targeted fixes.

Cybersecurity stocks like $PANW, $FTNT, $ZS, $RBRK & $CRWD are lower on fears AI-native security tools could pressure parts of the stack.

$GOOGL trying to build a TPU ecosystem outside of GCP by exploring spinning TPU into standalone unit while financing third-party data center partners to compete with $NVDA stack.

That includes investing ~$100M in Fluidstack at ~$8B valuation & backing projects tied to $CIFR, $HUT & $WULF to drive TPU demand.

$CRWV down ~12% after reports that $OWL couldn‚Äôt secure financing for a $4B data center project the two are co-developing.

Every megawatt CoreWeave can‚Äôt build is demand that flows to $AMZN AWS, $MSFT Azure or $GOOGL Cloud.

The AI workloads don‚Äôt disappear.

üö© $OWL is the tip of the iceberg.
Private credit is increasingly intertwined with BNPL and the banking system. It gets way worse. 

Banks provide funding to private credit vehicles, and private credit can, in turn, enter into forward-flow and similar financing arrangements with BNPL platforms such as $AFRM and Klarna.

We first laid out these risks (deep dive) for our Confidential Insights subscribers on November 30, 2025, and the logic has only become more relevant as the market searches for what sits behind the ‚Äúisolated events‚Äù narrative.
